title: Bus driver makes detour to drop crying girl home after she caught wrong service
text:

A kind-hearted bus driver took a detour to make sure an 11-year-old girl got home safely after she got on the wrong service.

The generous actions of Paul Comber have been praised by Patti O'Connell after he came to her daughter Megan's rescue when she took the wrong bus on Wednesday.

The 11-year-old was meant to get on the 418 New Ferry to Birkenhead route, but because she had to run for the bus she ended up on the 414 Woodside to New Brighton, the Liverpool Echo reports.

When Patti realised her daughter was late home she rang to see where she was but Megan was "sobbing and in a state" and couldn't describe the location she was at.

(Image: Liverpoool Echo WS)

Overhearing the schoolgirl in distress, Paul pulled into a lay-by and then spoke to Patti on the phone to reassure her he would get Megan home safely by making a detour.

The student nurse, from Beechwood in Merseyside, said: "My daughter usually gets the school bus home, but last night she had after school activities.

"Megan had to run for the bus and because of that she got on the 414 but was meant to get on the 418.

"She realised it wasn't the Upton route and started to panic.

"I rang her because she was late home and I started to worry when she answered she was really distressed.

"She was sobbing and in a state, I tried asking her to describe where she was but couldn't get her words out or describe anywhere.

"It was then the bus driver pulled over and spoke to me on the phone and really assured me and her he would get her home safe."

(Image: Liverpoool Echo WS)

The bus driver was due to finish his shift, but explained to Patti he would complete his route to New Brighton and then drop Megan at the bus stop at the bottom of her road.

The mum - who can't drive herself - said she had "never been so grateful" as trying to get a taxi to somewhere her daughter couldn't describe would be difficult.

She added: "I have never been so grateful because even to get a taxi or ring someone to pick her up could have meant Meg standing by herself and society isn't exactly great these days.

"I think if it was someone else they would have said for her to find her way back herself, but he still made sure he dropped her off even though he was meant to finish his shift.

"Megan has only just started getting the bus herself, so I think panic just set in - it was really nice for him to stop and assure me."

Patti said how Megan arrived at the door before she was able to thank Paul in person, but has since passed on her gratitude to Arriva.

It is believed that Paul has now been nominated for employee of the month for his heart-warming gesture.

Howard Farrall, Area Managing Director Arriva Merseyside said: "We’re incredibly proud of our driver Paul Comber for his actions during his route yesterday.

"Encouraging independent travel is something we’re really passionate about at Arriva and Paul's actions are a great example of how we can go above and beyond for customers.

"This incident could have had the potential to scare this young 11-year-old girl off buses for a long time, but thanks to Paul's actions he’s turned a negative situation into a real positive.

"Megan’s mum has been in touch to pass on her thanks to Paul, and we’re so pleased that we were able to get her home safely so her mum who was understandably very worried.

"It’s important to always let the driver know if yourself or a fellow customer finds themselves in difficulty."
description: Paul Comber has been praised by Patti O'Connell after he came to her daughter Megan's rescue on Wednesday
